docs.snippet: Something's Baking    A new organization for people interested in baking, Bakers Dozen East, is planning its first event for July 26. Betty Fussell, the author of "The Story of Corn" (Knopf, 1992, $30), is to give a presentation on cornmeal at 6 P...
docs.lead_paragraph: Something's Baking A new organization for people interested in baking, Bakers Dozen East, is planning its first event for July 26. Betty Fussell, the author of "The Story of Corn" (Knopf, 1992, $30), is to give a presentation on cornmeal at 6 P.M. at the Mark Hotel, 25 East 77th Street, Manhattan. Admission is $20. Bakers Dozen East is a fairly informal group -- no official whisks or rolling pins -- patterned after Bakers Dozen, a group organized by Marion Cunningham and Flo Braker in the San Francisco area. A number of professional bakers, pastry chefs, baking teachers and cookbook authors have already agreed to join Bakers Dozen East, which as yet has no rules, dues or other formalities. The group is open to nonprofessionals interested in sharing information about baking.

docs.snippet: PRESTON TURCO, owner of Turco's Super Ranch Specialty Supermarket in Hartsdale, spends time every day observing his customers' buying habits.   "The more I know about what draws customers into the store, the better," Mr. Turco said. "Today, people...
docs.lead_paragraph: PRESTON TURCO, owner of Turco's Super Ranch Specialty Supermarket in Hartsdale, spends time every day observing his customers' buying habits. "The more I know about what draws customers into the store, the better," Mr. Turco said. "Today, people are seeking freshness and quality. And they want variety."

headline.main: Lean Times? Not at the Specialty Grocer

docs.snippet: The State University of New York at Buffalo has expanded its mealtime repertory, offering fast-food counters on campus to win back some patrons who were lost to a new mini-mall and making meal plans compulsory for many students to insure that they...
docs.lead_paragraph: The State University of New York at Buffalo has expanded its mealtime repertory, offering fast-food counters on campus to win back some patrons who were lost to a new mini-mall and making meal plans compulsory for many students to insure that they buy food sold by the university. Until last spring, the university had the monopoly on selling meals through the dining halls on campus. That changed when a privately owned mini-mall was opened on the north campus, drawing students and faculty members with restaurants including Burger King and Pizza Hut and snacks like bagels, cookies and frozen yogurt.

headline.main: CAMPUS LIFE: SUNY, Buffalo; Amid Competition, College to Expand Its Food Offerings

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE way Judy Godino sees it, getting the family food through a cooperative buying club only looks like trouble. Granted, it entails planning weeks in advance, ordering in bulk, making sure someone can take time off from work to unload the delivery truck and separating everyone's order once it all arrives.

docs.snippet: THEY come in a stiff plastic bag with a label that makes almost no effort to attract a curious shopper's eye. ''Stuzzi with fennel seed'' it reads, a most humble way to describe the delicious crackers within.    Crackers, of course, are meant to b...
docs.abstract: watch a humble cracker make you it8
docs.lead_paragraph: THEY come in a stiff plastic bag with a label that makes almost no effort to attract a curious shopper's eye. ''Stuzzi with fennel seed'' it reads, a most humble way to describe the delicious crackers within. Crackers, of course, are meant to be humble food. Made of a dry, crisp dough of flour, water and salt, they are often a platform for other salty foods. But these little crackers, which are stubby and ridged much like radiatore pasta, are fabulous on their own. You can taste the olive oil, the salt, the flecks of fennel seed. They are firm and dry but relent under the teeth like good biscotti, without being bready or too filling. They are filling, though, because it is impossible to eat just one.

headline.main: Watch a Humble Cracker Make You Its Slave
